caption_original:
A new restriction temporarily prohibits the import of all species of salamanders, newts and mudpuppies, for one-year, unless authorized by a permit issued by Environment and Climate Change Canada. 

A deadly disease-causing fungus, suspected to have spread from Asia via the pet trade, has been devastating salamander populations in Europe.  Wild salamanders play a vital role in Canada’s ecosystems as part of the food web and in nutrient and carbon cycling. If the fungus enters Canadian ecosystems, the impacts on our native salamanders could be devastating. http://ow.ly/zZLd30ccnnz

Wild salamanders play a vital role in Canada’s ecosystems as part of the food web and in nutrient and carbon cycling. If the fungus enters Canadian ecosystems, the impacts on our native salamanders could be devastating.

caption_original:
Putting a price on carbon pollution is the cheapest and most effective way to reduce pollution and address climate change.
 
Carbon pricing allows us to put a price on what we don’t want—pollution—and supports what we do want: innovative technologies and cleaner communities.
caption_cleaned: Putting a price on carbon pollution is the cheapest and most effective way to reduce pollution and address climate change. Carbon pricing allows us to put a price on what we don’t want—pollution—and supports what we do want: innovative technologies and cleaner communities.

caption_original:
We are committed to providing clean air and healthier communities for Canadians by limiting air pollution.  

Reducing methane and other harmful emissions is also an important part of Canada’s plan to reach our climate change goals.
caption_cleaned: We are committed to providing clean air and healthier communities for Canadians by limiting air pollution. Reducing methane and other harmful emissions is also an important part of Canada’s plan to reach our climate change goals.

caption_original:
Some 30 Canadian companies, from Loblaws, to Canadian Tire, to the five big banks, have come out strongly in support of a price on pollution.

Canadian companies are choosing cleaner options as they produce and sell their products. They are making their operations more efficient. And they are putting bold ideas into action and creating good-paying middle-class jobs and opportunities in the process.

Countries from China to Chile to those in the European Union, and American states like Oregon and California – the sixth largest economy in the world – are all pricing carbon pollution. 

These major economies are putting a price on carbon pollution because it works, and because it is the most effective way to reach our emissions reductions goals while growing strong economies.
caption_cleaned: Some Canadian companies, from Loblaws, to Canadian Tire, to the five big banks, have come out strongly in support of a price on pollution. Canadian companies are choosing cleaner options as they produce and sell their products. They are making their operations more efficient. And they are putting bold ideas into action and creating good-paying middle-class jobs and opportunities in the process. Countries from China to Chile to those in the European Union, and American states like Oregon and California – the sixth largest economy in the world – are all pricing carbon pollution. These major economies are putting a price on carbon pollution because it works, and because it is the most effective way to reach our emissions reductions goals while growing strong economies.

caption_original:
Check out these weather instruments from the 1930s beside a home in Kamloops, British Columbia.

The four-cup anemometer on top of the pole is used to measure wind speed. The white louvered box is called a Stevenson Screen. It protects the sensitive thermometers from direct or reflected sunlight. #OdySci
caption_cleaned: Check out these weather instruments from the s beside a home in Kamloops, British Columbia. The four-cup anemometer on top of the pole is used to measure wind speed. The white louvered box is called a Stevenson Screen. It protects the sensitive thermometers from direct or reflected sunlight.

caption_original:
25 years ago, the UV Index was launched by Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists. Two years later, it was adopted by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, and it is now used internationally. 

The UV Index is a measure of the strength of the sun’s UV rays. It is based on the thickness of the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere, the angle of the sun above the horizon and the amount of cloud cover.  As the UV increases, the sun’s rays can do more harm to your skin, eyes and immune system.

Congratulations to Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists for developing such a useful tool! 👍🏼 http://ow.ly/6aIy30c4DeP
caption_cleaned: years ago, the UV Index was launched by Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists. Two years later, it was adopted by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, and it is now used internationally. It is based on the thickness of the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere, the angle of the sun above the horizon and the amount of cloud cover. As the UV increases, the sun’s rays can do more harm to your skin, eyes and immune system. Congratulations to Environment and Climate Change Canada’s scientists for developing such a useful tool!

Today, on #WorldTurtleDay, Environment and Climate Change Canada is proud to be working with Nature Conservancy of Canada to expand the protection of freshwater turtle habitat on Reid Island in the Outaouais Region and on Hébert Island in Quebec area. http://ow.ly/qbz330c01cY

caption_original:
Lake Erie needs your help! Harmful and nuisance algal blooms are hurting Lake Erie’s environment and economy, and present risks to human health. But a healthier lake is possible.

Canadians have until May 24 to comment on a draft action plan to help reduce the amount of phosphorus – a key factor causing algae – from entering the lake. Your comments and ideas will help build a final Plan with specific actions to help restore water quality in Lake Erie.

Public meetings are taking place on May 16 and 18 in the Lake Erie basin. Can’t make it in person?  Share your ideas online! www.letstalklakeerie.ca
caption_cleaned: Lake Erie needs your help! Harmful and nuisance algal blooms are hurting Lake Erie’s environment and economy, and present risks to human health. But a healthier lake is possible. Canadians have until May to comment on a draft action plan to help reduce the amount of phosphorus – a key factor causing algae – from entering the lake. Your comments and ideas will help build a final Plan with specific actions to help restore water quality in Lake Erie. Public meetings are taking place on May and in the Lake Erie basin. Can’t make it in person? Share your ideas online!

caption_original:
Did you know that methane emissions can be seen with an infrared camera? Using this technology to spot leaks could help oil and gas facilities capture previously wasted gas.

Reducing methane leaks through equipment is not just good for the environment; it’s good for Canada. This action will prevent the waste of Canada’s natural resources and ensure more methane is captured and available for sale by oil and gas companies.

This action will prevent the waste of Canada’s natural resources and ensure more methane is captured and available for sale by oil and gas companies.
